news.title: ZIDA approves over 200 new investment projects in Q1
news.content:
Story by Stanley James, Business Editor
ZIMBABWE’S target to become the region’s investment destination of choice is on course, amid revelations that over 200 new projects worth more than US$4 billion were approved by the Zimbabwe Investment and Development Agency (ZIDA) in the first three months of this year.
ZIDA’s first quarter report released to ZBC News this Friday shows a strong investor interest in several projects across the country.
The report notes an over 40 % rise in new investment licences issued compared to the same three months last year.
Matabeleland North Province dominated investment licences at over US$1.4 billion, followed by Mashonaland West province at more than US$800 million, Midlands Province at US$124 million and Harare at over US$110 million.

news.title: ZITF to end on a high note with star-studded Bulawayo shutdown gig
news.content:
Story by Lisa Masuku-Kirira
THE 65th edition of the Zimbabwe International Trade Fair (ZITF) is set to conclude on a high note with a vibrant line-up of entertainment and cultural experiences aimed at captivating both local and international visitors.
Running from April 21 to 26 in Bulawayo, this year’s ZITF will once again blend business with pleasure, as tradition dictates, offering attendees a rich cultural and musical celebration to wrap up the six-day international trade event.
“We aim to enrich the cultural, social, and musical aspects of ZITF. We have collaborated with Harris Entertainment to ensure visitors are thoroughly entertained,” ZITF’s Chief Executive Officer, Dr Nicholas Ndebele said.
One of the major entertainment programmes line-up is the Bulawayo shutdown gig.

news.title: Zim-China strengthen economic ties
news.content:
Story by Owen Mandovha
ZIMBABWE’S local industry is set to benefit from enhanced cooperation between Zimbabwe and China.
This follows a high-level engagement between the Executive Vice Governor of China’s Jiangsu Province, Mr Ma Xin, and the Minister of Industry and Commerce, Honourable Mangaliso Ndlovu, held in Harare this Wednesday.
The visit aims to explore investment opportunities and enhance capacity in key sectors of the economy such as leather manufacturing and pharmaceuticals.
“We are pleased to meet the Vice Governor of The Jiangsu Province, who has pledged to work with us in resuscitating the manufacturing sectors and of particular interest is the pharmaceuticals sector which is gobbling hundreds of millions of dollars in imports. The Chinese have pledged to make some investments locally to revive these sectors,” Honourable Ndlovu said.

news.title: Zim-Belarus strengthen trade ties with new agreements
news.content:
Story by Stanley James, Business Editor
DIPLOMATIC interactions between Zimbabwe and Belarus have recorded increased cooperation following the signing of agreements during the closing session of the Mid Term Review (MTR) of the Zimbabwe- Belarus Joint Permanent Commission on Cooperation (JPCC) in Harare this Wednesday.
The signing of an agreement on cooperation between AVM Africa of Zimbabwe and Aftrade of Belarus for the setting up of a bus assembly plant in Zimbabwe, was the major highlight of the session.
“The signing of additional agreements is testament to further consolidating the current trend with the key thrust being on the need to cement cordial relations. Going forward, we are committed to signing more agreements to bolster trade and investment,” Belarus’ Deputy Prime Minister, Honourable Victor Karankevich said.
Zimbabwe and Belarus also committed to the implementation of this and many other agreements, some of which were signed during previous sessions of the JPCC.
“Belarus is a long-term strategic partner for Zimbabwe and our aim is to enhance cooperation riding on the current gains. As such, there is need to continue revisiting the current agreements and focus on implementation as the hallmark for success,” Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Trade and Head of Zimbabwe’s Ministerial Delegation Professor Amon Murwira noted.
Key takeaways from the communique issued at the conclusion of the session include strengthened cooperation in agriculture, progress in bilateral relations across multiple sectors, and Zimbabwe’s heartfelt appreciation for Belarus’ humanitarian support during the El Nino-induced drought last year.

news.title: SADC defence delegation endorses GeoPomona waste management model
news.content:
Story by Owen Mandovha
THE SADC Military Health Working Group have been impressed by GeoPomona Waste to Energy Project, which they visited following the conclusion of their Annual General Meeting in Harare this Wednesday.
The Military Health Working Group’s interest in the project was to establish the uniqueness of the waste management initiative, which continues to attract admirers locally and internationally.
Their expectations were equally met and fit ideally into the working group’s one health concept as described by Lieutenant General Ntshaveni Maphaha of the South African Defence Forces and Brigadier General Jackson Kasela of the Zambian Defence Forces.
“When I was coming here, I thought that this is a dumpsite, but the project has impressed me to a larger extent and will form part of our recommendations,” Brigadier General Kasela said.
“Our mandate as the working group is to safeguard the population we work with. We visited this site so that we learn how we can make recommendations to our commanders,” Lieutenant General Ntshaveni Maphaha added.
